channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Dozens Killed as Militants Attack Kenyan Coastal Town
item.description: The authorities said the attack on a police station and two hotels in the coastal town of Mpeketoni was carried out by the Somali militant group Shabab.
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH and DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Morgue workers unloaded the bodies of some of those who were killed by militants in Mpeketoni, Kenya, a town near the tourist resort of Lamu Island.

item.title: Abdullah Campaign Alleges Widespread Election Fraud and Points at Karzai
item.description: Less than 48 hours after a runoff election, signs of a political crisis emerged with the campaign of Abdullah Abdullah claiming there had been widespread ballot stuffing.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG and AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Election workers moved ballot boxes on Sunday in Herat, Afghanistan.

item.title: Syrian Government Making Aid Delivery More Difficult, U.N. Official Says
item.description: The United Nations chief aid coordinator said the delivery of aid had become harder since President Bashar al-Assad claimed re-election on June 3.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Abdullah Campaign Alleges Widespread Election Fraud and Points at Karzai
item.description: Less than 48 hours after a runoff election, signs of a political crisis emerged with the campaign of Abdullah Abdullah claiming there had been widespread ballot stuffing.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG and AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Election workers moved ballot boxes on Sunday in Herat, Afghanistan.

item.title: U.S. and Iran Signaling New Joint Effort in Iraq Crisis
item.description: It would be the first such collaboration since the United States and Iran shared intelligence on the Taliban in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE, THOMAS ERDBRINK and MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Global Health: A Faster Way to Find the Origin of Malaria
item.description: A DNA “bar code” of 23 snips from the genes of parasites that cause malaria can help scientists quickly determine where they originated, British researchers report.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: June 16
item.description: A scene from a paddy field on the outskirts of Amritsar, Punjab.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Farmers working in a paddy field on the outskirts of Amritsar, Punjab.

item.title: China Executes 13 in Xinjiang Region After Attacks
item.description: The 13 people had been found guilty of organizing and leading terrorist groups, as well as murder, arson, theft and other crimes.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Sunni Rebels in Iraq Kill Shiite Volunteers and Seize New City
item.description: Iraqi extremists appeared to gain momentum on Monday as they took over the small city of Tal Afar in northwestern Iraq.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Iraqi security forces and tribal fighters on the outskirts of Diyala Province on Monday.

item.title: In Drive Against Taliban, Pakistani Airstrikes Hit Strongholds
item.description: The Pakistani military command said it had attacked six targets in the Shawal Valley of North Waziristan and killed 27 militant fighters.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH and SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Letter From Europe: Putin Puts Tough Image Before Words
item.description: There’s something about the Russian president’s body language that draws attention, and it’s not always flattering.
item.dc:creator: By CELESTINE BOHLEN
item.media:description: Vladimir V. Putin riding a horse during a 2009 vacation in southern Siberia.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Outrage After Pencil-Chewing Is Blamed for Lead Poisoning
item.description: Parents of children who showed high levels of lead in their blood believe that a local chemical plant is to blame, but a government official caused an uproar by suggesting that chewing pencils was the cause.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: India Ink: Modi Underscores Ties to Bhutan in First Foreign Visit
item.description: The newly elected prime minister concluded his first foreign visit to the neighboring country of Bhutan on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By VISHNU VARMA
item.media:description: Narendra Modi, prime minister of India, arriving at Bhutan's Paro Airport on Sunday.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Let North Korea Collapse
item.description: However destabilizing, the collapse of the house of Kim would be a necessary step toward reunifying the peninsula.
item.dc:creator: By SUE MI TERRY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Fetish of Staring at Iran’s Women
item.description: Western critics and Persian clerics alike have made women, and the way they dress, a false measure of Iranian society.
item.dc:creator: By HALEH ANVARI

item.title: Gazprom Stops Supplying Natural Gas to Ukraine
item.description: The Russian energy firm said it would no longer provide gas on credit, escalating the crisis between Kiev and Moscow and stirring fears about wider disruptions.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: The Ukrainian energy minister, Yuri Prodan, left, arrived at a meeting on Monday in Kiev with Gazprom's chief executive, Alexei Miller.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Meditations on the Beautiful Game
item.description: Soccer can be a source of many illusions, both good and bad — but mostly good.
item.dc:creator: By ENRIQUE KRAUZE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Father’s Day Plea to Educate China’s ‘Illegal’ Children
item.description: The suicide of a father of four in Guizhou Province in March aroused national debate on the practice, common in some areas, of “the kidnapping of education by family planning.”
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Children at a rural school in Min County, Gansu Province. Schools in China often demand to see a “family-planning certificate” from parents to prove a child’s legality under the "one-child policy."

item.title: Israel Demands Palestinian Leader’s Help After Abductions
item.description: The Israeli prime minister told President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority that he expected his assistance in finding three kidnapped teenagers.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Deadly Religious Violence Erupts in Sri Lanka
item.description: Three people were killed and scores injured in riots between Buddhists and Muslims in a southwestern coastal town.
item.dc:creator: By DHARISHA BASTIANS and GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Three Sentenced to Death Over Tiananmen Attack
item.description: A Chinese court sentenced three men to death on Monday for their roles in carrying out an attack near the entrance to Beijing’s Forbidden City in October that left five people dead and 40 injured.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Pakistan Military Wages Assault Against Militants
item.description: After fighter jets pounded militant targets in North Waziristan, the military announced that it had launched a “comprehensive operation” against militants in the region.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN and DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Some attempted to flee Miram Shah the main town in North Waziristan on Saturday, ahead of the offensive.

item.title: Colombian President Re-elected After a Race Challenging His Peace Negotiations
item.description: Voters elected Juan Manuel Santos to a second term, giving him a chance to complete talks with rebel groups that could end decades of guerrilla war.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Kaymer, Leading All the Way, Wins by 8 for His First U.S. Open Title
item.description: Martin Kaymer, who opened the tournament with a course-record 65, closed with a 69 at Pinehurst No. 2 for a 72-hole total of nine-under-par 271. He finished eight strokes ahead of Erik Compton and Rickie Fowler.
item.dc:creator: By BILL PENNINGTON
item.media:description: Martin Kaymer of Germany after winning the U.S. Open at Pinehurst Resort and Country Club.

item.title: Obama Pushes Iraqis to Mend Sectarian Rifts
item.description: The United States has asked Iraq’s prime minister to work with the Kurds to persuade the Sunni minority that the next government will be an “ally not an adversary,” an administration official said.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: President Obama returns to Washington on Monday, with a plan to urge Iraq’s leaders to form a unity government.
